title: Newsweek Polska
text:
Newsweek Polska is a <a href="Polish%20language">Polish language</a> weekly <a href="news%20magazine">news magazine</a> published in <a href="Poland">Poland</a> as the Polish edition of "<a href="Newsweek">Newsweek</a>".
History.
"Newsweek Polska" was established in 2001. The founder of the weekly is Tomasz Wróblewski.
The magazine is owned by <a href="Axel%20Springer">Axel Springer</a>. It is based in <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> and is published weekly on Mondays. Although it is a Polish version of "Newsweek", it does not fully cover the translations of the articles published in its parent magazine.
Tomasz Wróblewski was also the first <a href="editor-in-chief">editor-in-chief</a> and served in the post between 2001 and 2004, and then between 2005 and 2006. Jarosław Sroka was the editor-in-chief in 2004. From 2006 to 2009 Michał Kobosko was the editor-in-chief. He was replaced by Wojciech Maziarski who was in office between 2009 and 2012. Tomasz Lis has been the editor-in-chief of the weekly since 2012.
Ideology.
"Newsweek" has promoted a variety of views, mostly depending on those held by the current editor-in-chief, although it has traditionally been associated with <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a> politics, much like the "<a href="Gazeta%20Wyborcza">Gazeta Wyborcza</a>". Ever since Tomasz Lis took over as editor-in-chief, the magazine has taken a more radically anticlerical and anti-conservative approach; the editorial board is frequently subjected to criticism from <a href="Law%20and%20Justice">Law and Justice</a> leader <a href="Jaros%C5%82aw%20Kaczy%C5%84ski">Jarosław Kaczyński</a>. The cover of the 1 April 2015 issue featured Kaczyński with a caption saying "Assassin", implying his responsibility for the alleged "assassination" of Polish national unity in the aftermath of the <a href="Smolensk%20plane%20crash">2010 Smolensk plane crash</a>.
Circulation.
The circulation of "Newsweek Polska" in March 2009 was 192,000 copies. The magazine had a circulation of 114,309 copies in 2010 and 106,509 copies in 2011. It was 123,225 copies in 2012. The print and e-edition circulation of the weekly was 119,776 in August 2014. As of January 2020, circulation of "Newsweek Polska" was 67,700 copies.
